title_full: CBLDREL01-BP01 Use RAM and CPU limits
title: Use RAM and CPU limits
description: By default, a running container will use the full RAM and CPU of the host system. This can lead to performance bottlenecks on the host and put your workload in a degraded state. Setting RAM and CPU limits on your running container will improve the availability of the host system and the workload. Update the CPU and memory parameters in the task definition or deployment configuration to limit the resources a container will consume.
outcome: Improves system availability and prevents resource exhaustion by limiting container resource consumption.

title_full: CBLDREL02-BP01 Use volumes to persist data
title: Use volumes to persist data
description: Given the ephemeral nature of a container workload, data on the container will be lost once the container is restarted and no longer exists. Use mounted volumes, whether block or network file system (NFS), to persist file data for an application. Mounted volumes allow for file data sharing among multiple running containers. For persisting data, use external databases such as Amazon RDS, DynamoDB, or Aurora that provide performance, high-availability, and scalability.
outcome: Ensures data persistence and availability across container lifecycle events and enables data sharing between containers.

title: Create local testing processes
description: When building a containerized application, you want to be able to test your application as early as possible. Decide whether the container build for local testing will run on the developer's machine or remotely. Provide a local deployment mechanism using single containers as part of automation scripts or deploy containers locally using a local version of your target orchestrator. This can include using Docker Compose or minikube to deploy necessary infrastructure components in a lightweight fashion.
outcome: Enables early detection of issues and faster development cycles through local testing capabilities.

title_full: CBLDREL02-BP03 Design your testing environments to support your container build pipeline
title: Design your testing environments to support your container build pipeline
description: When building a containerized application, it can be easily deployed throughout multiple environments. To validate that your application is running properly, you will have to test your containerized applications. Create temporary or ephemeral testing environments with all dependent services already deployed. This process can be achieved with lower effort given the ease of reproducing fully configured environments based on containers using GitOps methodology or centralized deployment configuration.
outcome: Facilitates thorough testing through easily reproducible environments, improving application quality and reliability.

title_full: CBLDREL03-BP01 Create a standardized parent image
title: Create a standardized parent image
description: Based on a lean parent image, a team- or enterprise-wide image can be created that provides optimizations to all teams. This could be multiple parent images depending on the containerized application frameworks and languages. An organization could start with a lean image containing company-specific configurations, and teams can add additional software necessary to run different applications. Note that if a parent image is changed, all images that use it must also be recreated.
outcome: Provides consistent baseline configuration across the organization while allowing team-specific customizations.

title_full: CBLDREL03-BP02 Use an image hierarchy approach
title: Use an image hierarchy approach
description: Maintain an image hierarchy in your container image strategy. A hierarchy or layered approach to container images helps with maintenance, cascading of updates to base images, and allows for the reuse of container images. Separate images into categories: intermediate base image, application server, and application source code or binary. Operations like patching of a parent image should trigger a rebuild with changes to child images.
outcome: Simplifies maintenance and enables efficient update propagation through the image hierarchy.

title_full: CBLDREL03-BP03 Use source control and tagging on all container images
title: Use source control and tagging on all container images
description: Maintain the Dockerfile for all container images in a source control repository in the image hierarchy and ensure proper tagging of container images. Use a continuous integration process to create a direct correlation between the container images in source control and the image tag. This best practice is critical to determine what changed in the container image from a prior release.
outcome: Enables traceability and version control, making it easier to track changes and roll back if necessary.

title_full: CBLDREL04-BP01 Plan for health checks in all container builds and deployments
title: Plan for health checks in all container builds and deployments
description: When running container applications, there is no way of knowing whether the services running within a container are up or not without health checks. Adding a health check or probe to the container provides testing of the services in the container. Examine the orchestration systems health check and probing options, including liveness and readiness probes within Amazon EKS or health checks within a definition file within Amazon ECS.
outcome: Enables automatic detection and recovery from container failures, improving overall system reliability.
